Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploration of a New Class of Semiconductor Nanocrystals with Aliovalent Magnetic Dopants
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
This project supports an effort to develop the chemistry and physics of a class of multifunctional nanocrystals that can lead to new technologies based on advanced magnetic materials. More specifically, the project aims to elucidate the materials chemistry and electronic structures of earth-abundant nanocrystals containing specific amount of metal ions (dopants). This unique class of targeted dopant ions requires the presence of additional changes in the structure of nanocrystals. These materials have unique electronic structures at the nanoscale that can be controlled by varying the type of dopant ions and cochanging the concentration of electrons by external forces such as light. To accomplish this work, undergraduate and graduate students are being trained in both making the novel materials and measuring their electronic structures using sophisticated spectroscopy and electron microscopy. In particular, the recruitment and training of undergraduates from underrepresented groups to work on this project is enabled by the Collaborative Undergraduate Research in Energy (CURE) REU site at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Technical Abstract:
The hydrothermal synthesis of colloidal chromium(III)-doped strontium titanate nanocubes is applied to a variety of transition metal dopant ions known to substitute at the titanium(IV) site in the bulk. Examining these multifunctional materials as nanocrystals can impact a number of diverse applied research fields from visible-light photocatalysis to solid-state memories, and also serve as potential building blocks for multiferroic assemblies. The electronic structures of these diluted magnetic semiconductors are unique with aliovalent dopants compared to traditional, isovalent dopants, due to the potential redox levels that are within the band gap of the strontium titanate. As colloidal nanocrystals, these materials unlock new potential for altering the electronic structure through altering the defect chemistry at the surface, and providing a path for device fabrication by solution processing techniques. The objectives of this work are to (1) optimize the synthesis to yield and determine the electronic structures of a series of aliovalent diluted magnetic semiconductor nanocrystals, and (2) determine the effect of the Fermi level in the nanocrystals on the electronic structures and dopant-defect correlations. The unique electronic structures of the materials in this work also allows the nature of the charge-compensating defects to be compared between nanocrystals and bulk powders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER award supported the study of a new class of functional metal oxides with targeted dopant ions that introduce both charge carriers (aliovalent) and unpaired electrons (magnetic). We developed a general synthetic methodology to produce high-quality SrTiO3 and BaTiO3 colloidal nanocrystals with cubic shapes and tunable sizes ranging from 6-10 nm. Specific dopant ions that we explored were Cr3+, Mn4+/2+, and Fe3+. The successful preparation of these pure and doped colloidal Ti(IV)-based metal oxide nanocrystals allowed us to explore post-synthetic routes to perturb the material properties. We showed that anaerobic excitation of colloidal nanocrystals with UV light (photodoping) can generate up to ~200 Ti3+ defects per nanocrystal. These Ti3+ defects act as shallow electron donors and paramagnetic, leading to possible magnetic interactions with localized spins and redox-active dopant levels.

One of the significant outcomes of this award was the demonstration that the presence of Ti3+ defects in photodoped Cr3+-doped SrTiO3 colloidal nanocrystals accelerates the spin relaxation time of the Cr3+ spins through a near-resonant cross-relaxation process. We have studied a similar process in reduced Cr3+-doped SrTiO3 bulk powders, but the effect is not as dramatic due to heterogeneity in the distribution of Ti3+ defects throughout the powder. In the colloidal nanocrystal samples, this process is effective with every Cr3+ dopant and done at room temperature. Furthermore, the presence of the Ti3+ defects and associated properties are easily reversed by simply opening the sample to air. This work demonstrates a fast and straightforward way to modulate the relaxation dynamics of localized spins within a semiconductor host lattice, which provides useful information within the field of quantum information processing. We also discovered that these colloidal nanocrystals can also form reactive oxygen species during synthesis that is dependent on the amount of oxygen present in the reaction vessel during synthesis. These reactive oxygen species can also be generated post-synthetically by aerobic oxidation of the Ti3+ defects produced via photodoping. This aspect of the project provides promise for applying these materials as visible-light photocatalysts for the oxidative coupling of organic radicals found in natural gas feedstocks.
